page.title: 11THE PUBS OF NEWICK
page.content: The pubs of Newick are all old and very attractive buildings. The Bull, on the Green, was built in 1510 and used originally as a resting place for pilgrims. By 1793, it had been known by the various names of the Hatch, the Crown and the Bull and Butcher. As all good old buildings should, it claims to have its resident ghost - an orange cat! The Crown Hotel dates from 1820, when it was a coaching inn on the main London to Lewes road. The stables are still at the back. The Royal Oak dates from the 16th century and has the tradition of being the manor house, where manorial courts were held. It did not become an ale house until 1890. The Bricklayers' Arms is possibly of Tudor origin and was a brickworks until it became a beerhouse.
